children.subject:
1. CS 170; I did this my sophomore year as my only CS classes and it was plenty of work, but it's best to take 170 ASAP after taking 70 and 61B. It's a very typical combination.

2. No, it's not (for most people). You said you're having a hard time managing your current schedule and this plan is heavier. That being said, there are certain upper divs that are more manageable in combination--search the piazza for these or go on HKN's course guide. E.g. CS184 + 162 by itself would be tons of work while 161 + 162 would be more manageable.

3. This depends on which you want to emphasize more (SWE or quant. finance?). All of the classes you listed are potentially relevant for one or the other. I would start with taking 61C with 170, which will together introduce you to many SWE concepts as well as algorithmic problem solving and certain important mathematical concepts like FFT. Depending on which class or subtopic of each class you prefer, it will probably be clearer what you want to take next. Also search the piazza as many people have asked questions exactly like this. If I had to exclude a class from that list it would be 169.

hope it helps

history.content:
<md>170 is usually the first or second upper division CS class that CS majors do, mainly because if you follow the HKN course guide path to a tee, 170 is one of the few classes after CS 61B and 70 that can be taken; most other classes "require" CS 61C as well. 

61C as you've probably heard will be one of your top 3 CS classes period, as far as workload goes. If you're taking 20 units, you might want to think about something easier than 170, since 170 can be a difficult class for many.  Data 100 might be better for you if you intended to take that class.  Data 100 has a hard requirement of Data 8, so if you  haven't taken Data 8, you won't get in.  Do note that at some point, you're probably going to do 3 technicals in a semester and most if not all the CS classes either are decently difficult or high workload, or both.  

The 169A class is only offered in the Fall, and 169L in the Spring, but 169L requires 169A except for certain circumstances.  That's the one class you probably can skip if you're taking an internship since you'll be learning mostly the same things. Although if you're not doing an internship next summer, taking it in Fall 2022 wouldn't be the worst thing in the world, as it would help you with knowledge before going into an internship.</md>

Hey everyone!

I am a sophomore, taking cs 61b and eecs 16b this semester. I am going to declare cs at the end of this semester (i have taken cs 70 over the summer). I am having trouble managing my schedule and need advice from berkeley cs community:

  1. I am planning to take cs 61c with an upper-division next semester. Currently, I am thinking about taking data c100. Do you have any other class suggestions for taking with cs 61c next semester?
  2. Is the workload of taking 2 CS upper-divisions and 3 other classes (math/stat/econ) (total 20 units) manageable? Also, the same question for 3 CS upper-divisions and 2 other classes.
  3. I am currently thinking about which upper-divisions to take over the next 2 years; this my current list based on my interests and career path (I am interested in software engineering and quantitative finance): data 100, eecs 127, cs 161, 162, 169, 170, 182, 186, 188, 189. Any suggestions? Also, if you had to exclude one class from the following list (cs 161, 169, 170, 186), which one would it be?

thanks in advance
history.subject: Choosing Upper-division wisely
